docs.title: version Command
docs.text: The version command displays the current version of Recursivist.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: recursivist version

docs.title: Export Formats
docs.text: Recursivist can export directory structures to several different formats to suit different needs. This page explains each format and provides examples.

docs.title: Available Formats
docs.text: Format Extension Description Best For Text .txt Simple ASCII tree representation Quick reference, text-only environments JSON .json Structured data format for programmatic use Data processing, integration with tools HTML .html Interactive web-based visualization Sharing, documentation, web presentation Markdown .md GitHub-compatible Markdown representation Project documentation, README files React .jsx Interactive React component Web applications, interactive interfaces SVG .svg Vector image of the terminal output Embedding in documentation, sharing visuals

docs.title: Basic Export Command
docs.text:
To export the current directory structure:

recursivist export --format FORMAT

Replace FORMAT with one of: txt, json, html, md, jsx, or svg.

docs.title: Exporting to Multiple Formats
docs.text:
You can export to multiple formats in a single command:

recursivist export --format "txt json html md jsx"

docs.title: Specifying Output Directory
docs.text:
By default, exports are saved to the current directory. You can specify a different output directory:

recursivist export --format md --output-dir ./exports

docs.title: Customizing Filename Prefix
docs.text:
By default, all exports use the prefix structure. You can specify a different prefix:

recursivist export --format json --prefix my-project

This will create a file named my-project.json.

docs.title: Including File Statistics
docs.text:
All export formats support including file statistics:

# Include lines of code
recursivist export --format html --sort-by-loc

# Include file sizes
recursivist export --format json --sort-by-size

# Include modification times
recursivist export --format md --sort-by-mtime

# Combine multiple statistics
recursivist export --format txt --sort-by-loc --sort-by-size

docs.title: Text Format (TXT)
docs.text:
The text format provides a simple ASCII tree representation that can be viewed in any text editor:

📂 my-project
├── 📁 src
│   ├── 📄 main.py
│   ├── 📄 utils.py
│   └── 📁 tests
│       ├── 📄 test_main.py
│       └── 📄 test_utils.py
├── 📄 README.md
├── 📄 requirements.txt
└── 📄 setup.py

With file statistics:

📂 my-project (4328 lines)
├── 📁 src (3851 lines)
│   ├── 📄 main.py (245 lines)
│   ├── 📄 utils.py (157 lines)
│   └── 📁 tests (653 lines)
│       ├── 📄 test_main.py (412 lines)
│       └── 📄 test_utils.py (241 lines)
├── 📄 README.md (124 lines)
├── 📄 requirements.txt (18 lines)
└── 📄 setup.py (65 lines)

Export to text format with:

recursivist export --format txt

docs.title: JSON Format
docs.text:
The JSON format provides a structured representation that can be easily parsed by other tools or scripts:

{
  "root": "my-project",
  "structure": {
    "_files": ["README.md", "requirements.txt", "setup.py"],
    "src": {
      "_files": ["main.py", "utils.py"],
      "tests": {
        "_files": ["test_main.py", "test_utils.py"]
      }
    }
  }
}

With file statistics:

{
  "root": "my-project",
  "structure": {
    "_loc": 4328,
    "_files": [
      { "name": "README.md", "path": "README.md", "loc": 124 },
      { "name": "requirements.txt", "path": "requirements.txt", "loc": 18 },
      { "name": "setup.py", "path": "setup.py", "loc": 65 }
    ],
    "src": {
      "_loc": 3851,
      "_files": [
        { "name": "main.py", "path": "main.py", "loc": 245 },
        { "name": "utils.py", "path": "utils.py", "loc": 157 }
      ],
      "tests": {
        "_loc": 653,
        "_files": [
          { "name": "test_main.py", "path": "test_main.py", "loc": 412 },
          { "name": "test_utils.py", "path": "test_utils.py", "loc": 241 }
        ]
      }
    }
  },
  "show_loc": true,
  "show_size": false,
  "show_mtime": false
}

Export to JSON format with:

recursivist export --format json

docs.title: HTML Format
docs.text:
The HTML format provides an interactive web-based visualization that includes:

  • Proper styling for directories and files
  • Color-coding based on file extensions
  • File statistics display when enabled
  • Mobile-friendly responsive design
  • Clean, modern styling

Export to HTML format with:

recursivist export --format html

The generated HTML file can be opened in any web browser and includes appropriate styling and formatting.

docs.title: Markdown Format (MD)
docs.text:
The Markdown format creates a representation that renders nicely on platforms like GitHub:

# 📂 my-project

- 📁 **src**
  - 📄 `main.py`
  - 📄 `utils.py`
  - 📁 **tests**
    - 📄 `test_main.py`
    - 📄 `test_utils.py`
- 📄 `README.md`
- 📄 `requirements.txt`
- 📄 `setup.py`

With file statistics:

# 📂 my-project (4328 lines)

- 📁 **src** (3851 lines)
  - 📄 `main.py` (245 lines)
  - 📄 `utils.py` (157 lines)
  - 📁 **tests** (653 lines)
    - 📄 `test_main.py` (412 lines)
    - 📄 `test_utils.py` (241 lines)
- 📄 `README.md` (124 lines)
- 📄 `requirements.txt` (18 lines)
- 📄 `setup.py` (65 lines)

Export to Markdown format with:

recursivist export --format md

docs.title: React Component (JSX)
docs.text:
The JSX format creates a self-contained React component with an interactive directory tree viewer:

Features include:

  • Collapsible folder structure
  • Breadcrumb navigation
  • File and path search functionality
  • Path copying
  • Dark/light mode toggle
  • Tree navigation with keyboard shortcuts
  • File statistics display when enabled
  • Expand/collapse all buttons
  • Mobile-responsive design
  • Smooth animations and transitions

Export to React component format with:

recursivist export --format jsx

docs.title: SVG Format
docs.text:
The SVG format creates a beautiful, scalable vector graphic image of your directory structure exactly as it would appear in your terminal. It preserves all rich color-coding, icons, and formatting.

Export to SVG format with:

recursivist export --format svg

docs.title: Using the React Component
docs.text:
To use the exported React component in your project:

  1. Copy the generated .jsx file to your React project's components directory
  2. Install the required dependencies: 
    npm install lucide-react prop-types
  3. Import and use the component in your application:
import DirectoryViewer from "./components/structure.jsx";

function App() {
  return (
    <div className="App">
      <DirectoryViewer />
    </div>
  );
}

The component is designed to be used with Tailwind CSS. If your project doesn't use Tailwind, you may need to adapt the component to use your preferred styling solution.

docs.title: Export with Filtering
docs.text:
All of the filtering options available for the visualize command also work with the export command:

recursivist export \
--format md \
--exclude "node_modules .git" \
--exclude-ext .pyc \
--depth 3

This exports a Markdown representation of the directory structure, excluding node_modules and .git directories, as well as .pyc files, and limiting the depth to 3 levels.

docs.title: Exporting Full Paths
docs.text:
By default, exports show only filenames. You can include full paths with the --full-path option:

recursivist export --format json --full-path

This is particularly useful for JSON exports that might be processed by other tools.

docs.title: Comparison of Export Formats
docs.text:
Feature TXT JSON HTML MD JSX SVG Human-readable ✅ ⚠️ ✅ ✅ ⚠️ ✅ Machine-readable ⚠️ ✅ ⚠️ ⚠️ ⚠️ ❌ Interactive ❌ ❌ ✅ ❌ ✅ ❌ Search functionality ❌ ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅ ❌ File statistics support ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ Color-coding ✅ ❌ ✅ ⚠️ ✅ ✅ Collapsible structure ❌ ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅ ❌ Requires external libraries ❌ ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅ ❌

Legend:

  • ✅ Fully supported
  • ⚠️ Partially supported
  • ❌ Not supported

docs.title: Pattern Matching
docs.text: This reference guide explains the pattern matching capabilities in Recursivist, covering both glob patterns and regular expressions.

docs.title: Pattern Types
docs.text:
Recursivist supports two types of patterns:

  1. Glob patterns (default): Simple wildcard-based patterns familiar to shell users
  2. Regular expressions: More powerful pattern matching syntax for complex cases

docs.title: Glob Patterns
docs.text: By default, Recursivist uses glob patterns for matching files and directories.

docs.title: Glob Syntax
docs.text: Pattern Meaning * Matches any number of characters (except /) ? Matches a single character (except /) [abc] Matches one character in the brackets [!abc] Matches one character not in the brackets ** Matches any number of directories (recursive)

docs.title: Glob Examples
docs.text: Pattern Matches Does Not Match *.js app.js, utils.js app.jsx, utils.ts *.test.js app.test.js, utils.test.js app.js, test.js src/* src/app.js, src/utils.js src/components/button.js src/**/*.js src/app.js, src/components/button.js app.js, src/app.ts test?.js test1.js, testA.js test.js, test10.js [abc]*.js a.js, b123.js, capp.js d.js, xyz.js [!abc]*.js d.js, xyz.js a.js, b123.js

docs.title: Using Glob Patterns
docs.text:
Glob patterns are used with the --exclude-pattern and --include-pattern options:

recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "*.test.js" "*.spec.js"
recursivist visualize --include-pattern "src/**/*.js" "docs/*.md"

docs.title: Regular Expressions
docs.text: For more complex pattern matching, you can use regular expressions by adding the --regex flag.

docs.title: Regex Syntax
docs.text:
Regular expressions in Recursivist follow Python's regex syntax. Some common elements:

Pattern Meaning . Matches any character except newline ^ Matches the start of a string $ Matches the end of a string * Matches 0 or more repetitions + Matches 1 or more repetitions ? Matches 0 or 1 repetition \d Matches a digit \w Matches a word character \s Matches a whitespace character [abc] Matches any character in the brackets [^abc] Matches any character not in the brackets a\|b Matches either a or b (...) Capture group (?:...) Non-capturing group

Special characters need to be escaped with a backslash, e.g., \. to match a literal period.

docs.title: Regex Examples
docs.text: Pattern Matches Does Not Match ^test_.*\.py$ test_app.py, test_utils.py app_test.py, test.py .*\.(spec\|test)\.(js\|ts)$ app.test.js, utils.spec.ts app.js, test.js ^src/.*\.jsx?$ src/app.js, src/utils.jsx src/app.ts, lib/app.js ^(?!.*test).*\.py$ app.py, utils.py app_test.py, test_utils.py \d+_.*\.log$ 123_server.log, 2_app.log server.log, app_123.log

docs.title: Using Regex Patterns
docs.text:
To use regular expressions, add the --regex flag:

recursivist visualize \
--exclude-pattern "^test_.*\.py$" ".*_test\.js$" \
--regex

recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "^src/.*\.(jsx?|tsx?)$" \
--regex

docs.title: Pattern Precedence
docs.text:
When multiple patterns are specified, Recursivist applies them in the following order:

  1. Include patterns (if specified, only matching files will be considered)
  2. Exclude patterns (matching files are excluded)
  3. Excluded extensions (files with matching extensions are excluded)
  4. Excluded directories (directories matching these names are excluded)
  5. Gitignore patterns (if specified, patterns from the ignore file are applied)

This means that include patterns have the highest precedence and can override all other exclusions.

docs.title: Combining Include and Exclude Patterns
docs.text:
You can use both include and exclude patterns together:

recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "src/**/*.js" "docs/*.md" \
--exclude-pattern "**/node_modules/*" "**/*.min.js"

In this case, only files that match at least one include pattern will be considered, and among those, files matching any exclude pattern will be excluded.

docs.title: Pattern Matching in Different Commands
docs.text:
Pattern matching works the same way across all Recursivist commands:

  • visualize: Control what files and directories are displayed
  • export: Control what's included in the exported file
  • compare: Control what's considered when comparing directories

docs.title: Show Only Source Code
docs.text:
# Glob pattern
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "src/**/*"

# Regex pattern
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "^src/" \
--regex

docs.title: Exclude All Test Files
docs.text:
# Glob pattern
recursivist visualize \
--exclude-pattern "**/*.test.js" "**/*.spec.js" "test/**/*"

# Regex pattern
recursivist visualize \
--exclude-pattern ".*\.(test|spec)\.[jt]sx?$" "^test/" \
--regex

docs.title: Show Only Specific File Types
docs.text:
# Glob pattern
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "**/*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}"

# Regex pattern
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern ".*\.[jt]sx?$" \
--regex

docs.title: Complex Filtering with Regex
docs.text:
# Include JavaScript modules, exclude test files and minified files
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "^src/.*\.js$" \
--exclude-pattern ".*\.(test|spec)\.js$" ".*\.min\.js$" \
--regex

docs.title: Pattern Matching with File Statistics
docs.text:
To focus on important code metrics, combine pattern matching with file statistics:

# Find large source files
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "src/**/*.js" \
--sort-by-size

# Identify complex modules
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "src/**/*.py" \
--exclude-pattern "**/*test*.py" \
--sort-by-loc

# See recent changes to specific areas
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "src/components/**/*.jsx" \
--sort-by-mtime

docs.title: Filter Based on File Contents (Gitignore Style)
docs.text:
When using a gitignore-style file with the --ignore-file option, you can use patterns that work similarly to .gitignore files:

# .recursivist-ignore
*.log
node_modules/
**/dist/
*~

Then use it with:

recursivist visualize \
--ignore-file .recursivist-ignore

docs.title: Performance Considerations
docs.text:
• Glob patterns are generally faster than regex patterns
  • Complex regex patterns can be slower on large directory structures
  • Include patterns can improve performance by reducing the number of files to process

docs.title: Development Project
docs.text:
recursivist visualize \
--exclude "node_modules .git build dist" \
--exclude-ext ".min.js .map"

docs.title: Documentation Project
docs.text:
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "**/*.md" "**/*.rst" "**/*.txt" "docs/**/*"

docs.title: Source Code Analysis
docs.text:
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "src/**/*" \
--exclude-pattern "**/*.test.js" "**/*.spec.js"

docs.title: Backend Development
docs.text:
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "**/*.py" "**/*.go" "**/*.java" \
--exclude-pattern "**/*_test.py" "**/*_test.go" "**/*Test.java"

docs.title: Troubleshooting Pattern Matching
docs.text:
If your patterns aren't working as expected:

  1. Use verbose mode: Run with --verbose to see detailed logging about pattern matching
  2. Test simpler patterns first: Start with basic patterns and build up complexity
  3. Check pattern syntax: Ensure you're using the correct syntax for glob or regex
  4. Remember path conventions: Patterns match against relative paths from the root directory
  5. Check precedence: Remember that include patterns override exclude patterns

For debugging complex regex patterns, consider testing them in a regex tool like regex101.com before using them in Recursivist.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text: Recursivist is designed to be intuitive and easy to use while offering powerful capabilities. This guide covers the basic concepts and usage patterns.

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
All Recursivist commands follow a consistent structure:

recursivist [command] [options] [arguments]

Where:

  • command is one of: visualize, export, compare, completion, or version
  • options are optional flags that modify the command's behavior
  • arguments are typically directory paths or other positional arguments

docs.title: Checking Version
docs.text:
To check which version of Recursivist you have installed:

recursivist version

docs.title: Visualizing the Current Directory
docs.text:
To display a tree representation of the current directory:

recursivist visualize

This will show a colorful tree of all files and directories, with each file type color-coded for easy identification.

docs.title: Visualizing a Specific Directory
docs.text:
To visualize a different directory:

recursivist visualize /path/to/directory

docs.title: Visualizing with File Statistics
docs.text:
Recursivist can display and sort by various file statistics:

# Show lines of code
recursivist visualize --sort-by-loc

# Show file sizes
recursivist visualize --sort-by-size

# Show modification times
recursivist visualize --sort-by-mtime

# Combine multiple statistics
recursivist visualize --sort-by-loc --sort-by-size

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
To see all available commands:

recursivist --help

To get help for a specific command:

recursivist visualize --help
recursivist export --help
recursivist compare --help

docs.title: Default Behavior
docs.text:
By default, Recursivist:

  • Shows all files and directories in the specified location
  • Doesn't limit the depth of the directory tree
  • Displays only filenames (not full paths)
  • Colors files based on their extensions
  • Uses Unicode characters for the tree structure

You can modify this behavior using the various options described in the following sections.

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: These options work with most Recursivist commands:

docs.title: Excluding Directories
docs.text:
To exclude specific directories:

recursivist visualize --exclude "node_modules .git"

docs.title: Excluding File Extensions
docs.text:
To exclude files with specific extensions:

recursivist visualize --exclude-ext ".pyc .log"

docs.title: Limiting Depth
docs.text:
To limit how deep the directory tree goes:

recursivist visualize --depth 3

docs.title: Showing Full Paths
docs.text:
To show full file paths instead of just names:

recursivist visualize --full-path

docs.title: Using Verbose Mode
docs.text:
For more detailed output and logging:

recursivist visualize --verbose

docs.title: Pattern Filtering
docs.text: Recursivist offers powerful pattern-based filtering options:

docs.title: Glob Patterns (Default)
docs.text:
# Exclude test files
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "*.test.js" "*.spec.js"

docs.title: Regular Expressions
docs.text:
# Exclude test files using regex
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "^test_.*\.py$" --regex

docs.title: Include Patterns (Override Exclusions)
docs.text:
# Only include specific files/directories
recursivist visualize --include-pattern "src/**/*.js" "*.md"

docs.title: Gitignore Integration
docs.text:
# Use patterns from a gitignore-style file
recursivist visualize --ignore-file .gitignore

docs.title: Export Formats
docs.text:
Export directory structures to various formats:

# Export to Markdown
recursivist export --format md

# Export to JSON
recursivist export --format json

# Export to HTML
recursivist export --format html

# Export to plain text
recursivist export --format txt

# Export to React component
recursivist export --format jsx

docs.title: Directory Comparison
docs.text:
Compare two directory structures:

# Basic comparison
recursivist compare dir1 dir2

# Save comparison as HTML
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --save

docs.title: Shell Completion
docs.text:
Generate shell completion scripts:

# For Bash
recursivist completion bash > ~/.bash_completion.d/recursivist

# For Zsh, Fish, or PowerShell
recursivist completion zsh|fish|powershell

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text:
Recursivist uses standard exit codes to indicate success or failure:

  • 0: Success
  • 1: General error (like invalid arguments or directories)
  • Other non-zero values: Specific error conditions

These exit codes can be useful when incorporating Recursivist into scripts or automation.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you're familiar with the basic usage, you can explore:

  • Visualization options for customizing how directory trees are displayed
  • Export formats for saving directory structures
  • Comparison features for identifying differences between directories
  • Pattern filtering for precisely controlling what's included/excluded

docs.title: Compare
docs.text: The compare command allows you to compare two directory structures side by side with highlighted differences. This guide explains how to use it effectively.

docs.title: Basic Comparison
docs.text:
To compare two directories:

recursivist compare dir1 dir2

This will display both directory trees side by side in the terminal, with highlighted differences between them.

docs.title: Understanding the Output
docs.text:
The comparison output uses color highlighting to show differences:

  • Items that exist in both directories are displayed normally
  • Items unique to directory 1 are highlighted in green
  • Items unique to directory 2 are highlighted in red

A legend explains the color coding at the top of the output.

docs.title: Including File Statistics
docs.text:
You can include file statistics in the comparison:

# Include lines of code
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --sort-by-loc

# Include file sizes
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --sort-by-size

# Include modification times
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --sort-by-mtime

# Combine multiple statistics
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --sort-by-loc --sort-by-size

This makes it easy to see not just structural differences but also differences in file content size, modification time, or other metrics.

docs.title: Exporting Comparison Results
docs.text:
By default, the comparison is displayed in the terminal. To save it as an HTML file:

recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --save

This creates an HTML file named comparison.html in the current directory.

To specify a different output directory:

recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --save --output-dir ./reports

To customize the filename prefix:

recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --save --prefix project-diff

This creates a file named project-diff.html.

docs.title: Filtering the Comparison
docs.text: All of the filtering options available for other Recursivist commands also work with compare:

docs.title: Excluding Directories
docs.text: recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --exclude "node_modules .git"

docs.title: Excluding File Extensions
docs.text: recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --exclude-ext ".pyc .log"

docs.title: Pattern-Based Filtering
docs.text:
# Exclude with glob patterns (default)
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --exclude-pattern "*.test.js"

# Exclude with regex patterns
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --exclude-pattern "^test_.*\.py$" --regex

# Include only specific patterns
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --include-pattern "src/*" "*.md"

See the Pattern Filtering guide for more details.

docs.title: Using Gitignore Files
docs.text: recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --ignore-file .gitignore

docs.title: Depth Control
docs.text:
For large directories, limit the comparison depth:

recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --depth 3

docs.title: Full Path Display
docs.text:
To show full paths instead of just filenames:

recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --full-path

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text: The comparison feature is particularly useful for:

docs.title: Project Evolution
docs.text:
Compare different versions of a project:

recursivist compare project-v1.0 project-v2.0

docs.title: Code Reviews
docs.text:
Compare branches or pull requests:

# Clone the branches to compare
git clone -b main repo main-branch
git clone -b feature/new-feature repo feature-branch

# Compare directory structures
recursivist compare main-branch feature-branch

docs.title: Deployment Verification
docs.text:
Compare local development and production environments:

recursivist compare local-build production-build

docs.title: Backup Validation
docs.text:
Compare original files with backups:

recursivist compare original-files backup-files

docs.title: Basic Comparison
docs.text: recursivist compare project-v1 project-v2

docs.title: Compare with Exclusions
docs.text:
recursivist compare project-v1 project-v2 \
--exclude "node_modules .git" \
--exclude-ext ".pyc .log"

docs.title: Compare with Depth Limit and HTML Export
docs.text:
recursivist compare project-v1 project-v2 \
--depth 3 \
--save \
--output-dir ./reports \
--prefix version-comparison

docs.title: Compare Source Directories Only
docs.text:
recursivist compare project-v1/src project-v2/src \
--include-pattern "*.js" "*.css" "*.jsx"

docs.title: Compare with File Statistics
docs.text:
recursivist compare project-v1 project-v2 \
--sort-by-loc \
--sort-by-size

docs.title: HTML Output Features
docs.text:
When exporting to HTML (--save option), the generated file includes:

  • Interactive, side-by-side comparison
  • Color-coded highlighting of differences
  • Responsive layout that works on different screen sizes
  • Proper styling for directories and files
  • File statistics display when enabled
  • Detailed metadata about the comparison settings
  • Visual legend explaining the highlighting scheme

This is useful for sharing comparison results with team members or keeping records of structural changes.

docs.title: Terminal Compatibility
docs.text:
The terminal comparison view works best in terminals with:

  • Unicode support for special characters
  • ANSI color support
  • Sufficient width to display side-by-side content

For narrow terminals, the comparison may not display optimally. In these cases, using the HTML export option (--save) is recommended.

docs.title: Export
docs.text: The export command allows you to save directory structures to various file formats. This guide covers how to use the export features effectively.

docs.title: Basic Export Usage
docs.text:
To export the current directory structure:

recursivist export --format FORMAT

Replace FORMAT with one of: txt, json, html, md, or jsx.

For a specific directory:

recursivist export /path/to/directory --format FORMAT

docs.title: Available Export Formats
docs.text:
Recursivist supports multiple export formats, each suitable for different purposes:

Format Extension Description Use Case Text .txt Simple ASCII tree Quick reference, text-only environments JSON .json Structured data Integration with other tools, processing HTML .html Web-based view Sharing, web documentation Markdown .md GitHub-compatible Documentation, GitHub readmes React .jsx Interactive component Web applications, dashboards SVG .svg Vector image Embedding in READMEs, sharing visuals

docs.title: Exporting to Multiple Formats
docs.text:
You can export to multiple formats in a single command:

# Space-separated formats
recursivist export --format "txt json html md"

# Multiple format flags
recursivist export --format txt --format json --format html

docs.title: Output Directory
docs.text:
By default, exports are saved to the current directory. To specify a different location:

recursivist export --format md --output-dir ./exports

This will create a file at ./exports/structure.md.

docs.title: Customizing Filenames
docs.text:
By default, all exports use the prefix structure. You can specify a different prefix:

recursivist export --format json --prefix my-project

This will create a file named my-project.json.

docs.title: Including File Statistics
docs.text:
You can include statistics in your exports, just like with the visualize command:

# Include lines of code in export
recursivist export --format md --sort-by-loc

# Include file sizes
recursivist export --format html --sort-by-size

# Include modification times
recursivist export --format json --sort-by-mtime

# Combine multiple statistics
recursivist export --format md --sort-by-loc --sort-by-size

These statistics will be included in the export file with appropriate formatting for each format.

docs.title: Filtering Exports
docs.text:
All of the filtering options available for the visualize command also work with export:

recursivist export --format md \
--exclude "node_modules .git" \
--exclude-ext .pyc \
--exclude-pattern "*.test.js"

See the Pattern Filtering guide for more details on filtering options.

docs.title: Depth Control
docs.text:
For large projects, you can limit the export depth:

recursivist export --format html --depth 3

docs.title: Full Path Display
docs.text:
By default, exports show only filenames. To include full paths:

recursivist export --format json --full-path

This is particularly useful for JSON exports that might be processed by other tools.

docs.title: Text Format (.txt)
docs.text:
The text format provides a simple ASCII tree view:

📂 my-project
├── 📁 src
│   ├── 📄 main.py
│   └── 📄 utils.py
├── 📄 README.md
└── 📄 setup.py

This format works well in environments where Unicode is supported.

docs.title: JSON Format (.json)
docs.text:
The JSON format provides a structured representation:

{
  "root": "my-project",
  "structure": {
    "src": {
      "_files": ["main.py", "utils.py"]
    },
    "_files": ["README.md", "setup.py"]
  }
}

When file statistics are included:

{
  "root": "my-project",
  "structure": {
    "_loc": 4328,
    "src": {
      "_loc": 3851,
      "_files": [
        { "name": "main.py", "path": "main.py", "loc": 245 },
        { "name": "utils.py", "path": "utils.py", "loc": 157 }
      ]
    },
    "_files": [
      { "name": "README.md", "path": "README.md", "loc": 124 },
      { "name": "setup.py", "path": "setup.py", "loc": 65 }
    ]
  },
  "show_loc": true,
  "show_size": false,
  "show_mtime": false
}

This format is ideal for programmatic processing or integration with other tools.

docs.title: HTML Format (.html)
docs.text:
The HTML format creates a web page with an interactive directory structure. It includes:

  • Proper styling for directories and files
  • Color coding based on file types
  • Statistics display when enabled
  • Responsive design for viewing on different devices

When file statistics are included, they are displayed next to each file and directory with appropriate styling.

docs.title: Markdown Format (.md)
docs.text:
The Markdown format creates a representation that renders well on platforms like GitHub:

# 📂 my-project

- 📁 **src**
  - 📄 `main.py`
  - 📄 `utils.py`
- 📄 `README.md`
- 📄 `setup.py`

With statistics:

# 📂 my-project (4328 lines)

- 📁 **src** (3851 lines)
  - 📄 `main.py` (245 lines)
  - 📄 `utils.py` (157 lines)
- 📄 `README.md` (124 lines)
- 📄 `setup.py` (65 lines)

docs.title: React Component (.jsx)
docs.text:
The JSX format creates an interactive React component with:

  • Collapsible folder structure
  • Search functionality
  • Breadcrumb navigation
  • Path copying
  • Dark mode toggle
  • File statistics display when enabled
  • Expand/collapse all buttons
  • Mobile-responsive design

This is the most sophisticated export option, designed for integration into web applications.

docs.title: SVG Format (.svg)
docs.text: The SVG format captures an exact image of the terminal visualization, preserving all colors, icons, and tree structures in a scalable vector graphic. This is perfect for embedding your directory structure directly into project READMEs or documentation without losing the beautiful terminal styling.

docs.title: Using the React Component
docs.text:
To use the exported React component in your project:

  1. Copy the generated .jsx file to your React project's components directory
  2. Install required dependencies: 
    npm install lucide-react
  3. Import and use the component:
import DirectoryViewer from "./components/structure.jsx";

function App() {
  return (
    <div className="App">
      <DirectoryViewer />
    </div>
  );
}

The component is designed to work with Tailwind CSS. If your project doesn't use Tailwind, you'll need to adapt the component accordingly.

docs.title: Basic Export to Markdown
docs.text: recursivist export --format md

docs.title: Export to Multiple Formats with Custom Prefix
docs.text:
recursivist export \
--format "txt md json" \
--prefix project-structure \
--output-dir ./docs

docs.title: Export Source Directory Only
docs.text:
recursivist export src \
--format html \
--prefix source-structure

docs.title: Export with Depth Control and Exclusions
docs.text:
recursivist export \
--format jsx \
--depth 3 \
--exclude "node_modules .git" \
--exclude-ext ".log .tmp"

docs.title: Export with File Statistics
docs.text:
recursivist export \
--format html \
--sort-by-loc \
--sort-by-size \
--sort-by-mtime

For more detailed information about export formats, see the Export Formats reference.

docs.title: Pattern Filtering
docs.text: Recursivist provides powerful pattern-based filtering to help you focus on the files and directories that matter most. This guide explains the different filtering methods available.

docs.title: Excluding Directories
docs.text:
To exclude specific directories from the visualization or export, you can specify multiple directories either as space-separated values with a single flag or with multiple flags:

# Space-separated
recursivist visualize --exclude "node_modules .git venv"

# Multiple flags
recursivist visualize --exclude node_modules --exclude .git --exclude venv

docs.title: Excluding File Extensions
docs.text:
To exclude files with specific extensions:

recursivist visualize --exclude-ext ".pyc .log .cache"

File extensions can be specified with or without the leading dot (.), as Recursivist normalizes them internally.

docs.title: Using Gitignore Files
docs.text:
If you have a .gitignore file (or similar), you can use it to filter the directory structure:

recursivist visualize --ignore-file .gitignore

You can also specify a different file:

recursivist visualize --ignore-file .recursivist-ignore

docs.title: Glob Pattern Filtering
docs.text:
By default, Recursivist supports glob patterns for filtering:

# Exclude all JavaScript test files
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "*.test.js" "*.spec.js"

# Exclude all Python cache files and directories
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "__pycache__" "*.pyc"

Glob patterns use simple wildcard characters:

  • *: Matches any number of characters
  • ?: Matches a single character
  • [abc]: Matches one character in the brackets
  • [!abc]: Matches one character not in the brackets
  • **: Matches directories recursively (e.g., src/**/*.js matches all JS files in src and subdirectories)

docs.title: Regex Pattern Filtering
docs.text:
For more complex patterns, you can use regular expressions by adding the --regex flag:

# Exclude files starting with "test_" and ending with ".py"
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "^test_.*\.py$" --regex

# Exclude both JavaScript and TypeScript test files
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern ".*\.(spec|test)\.(js|ts)$" --regex

Regular expressions provide more powerful matching capabilities but can be more complex to write.

docs.title: Include Patterns
docs.text:
Sometimes it's easier to specify what you want to include rather than what you want to exclude. For this, use the --include-pattern option:

# Include only source code files and documentation
recursivist visualize --include-pattern "src/**/*.js" "docs/*.md"

When you specify include patterns, they take precedence over exclude patterns. Only files that match at least one include pattern will be shown.

With regex:

# Include only React components and their tests
recursivist visualize --include-pattern "^src/.*\.(jsx|tsx)$" "^src/.*\.test\.(jsx|tsx)$" --regex

docs.title: Combining Filters
docs.text:
You can combine different filtering methods for precise control:

recursivist visualize \
--exclude "node_modules .git" \
--exclude-ext ".pyc .log" \
--exclude-pattern "*.test.js" \
--include-pattern "src/*" "*.md" \
--ignore-file .gitignore

docs.title: Filter Order of Precedence
docs.text:
When multiple filtering methods are used, Recursivist applies them in the following order:

  1. Include patterns (if specified, only matching files will be considered)
  2. Exclude patterns (matching files are excluded)
  3. Excluded extensions (files with matching extensions are excluded)
  4. Excluded directories (directories matching these names are excluded)
  5. Gitignore patterns (if specified, patterns from the ignore file are applied)

This means that include patterns have the highest precedence and can override all other exclusions.

docs.title: Focus on Source Code Only
docs.text: recursivist visualize --include-pattern "src/*"

docs.title: Exclude Generated Files
docs.text: recursivist visualize --exclude "dist build coverage" --exclude-ext ".min.js .map"

docs.title: View Only Documentation
docs.text: recursivist visualize --include-pattern "*.md" "*.rst" "docs/*"

docs.title: Complex Filtering with Regex
docs.text:
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "^src/.*\.(jsx?|tsx?)$" \
--exclude-pattern ".*\.(spec|test)\.(jsx?|tsx?)$" \
--regex

This includes only JavaScript and TypeScript source files from the src directory, but excludes test files.

docs.title: Filtering with File Statistics
docs.text:
You can combine filtering with file statistics to focus on specific aspects of your codebase:

# Show only source files with more than 100 lines
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "src/**/*.py" \
--sort-by-loc

# Find largest files in a specific directory
recursivist visualize \
--include-pattern "assets/**/*" \
--sort-by-size

# See recently modified files
recursivist visualize \
--exclude "node_modules .git" \
--sort-by-mtime

While Recursivist doesn't directly filter by the statistics themselves (like "show only files larger than X"), sorting by these metrics helps identify key files of interest.

docs.title: Filtering in Export and Compare Commands
docs.text:
All the filtering techniques described above work the same way with the export and compare commands:

# Export only source files
recursivist export --format md --include-pattern "src/**/*.js"

# Compare only specific directories
recursivist compare dir1 dir2 --include-pattern "src/*" "config/*"

This consistency across commands allows you to apply the same filtering logic regardless of the operation you're performing.

docs.title: Shell Completion
docs.text: Recursivist supports shell completion for easier command entry. This guide explains how to set up and use shell completion for different shells.

docs.title: What is Shell Completion?
docs.text:
Shell completion allows you to press the Tab key while typing a command to:

  • Complete command names, options, and arguments
  • See available options and subcommands
  • Auto-complete file and directory paths

This makes Recursivist faster and easier to use from the command line.

docs.title: Generating Completion Scripts
docs.text:
Recursivist can generate shell completion scripts for different shells:

  • Bash
  • Zsh
  • Fish
  • PowerShell

Use the completion command to generate the appropriate script:

recursivist completion SHELL

Replace SHELL with one of: bash, zsh, fish, or powershell.

docs.title: Setting Up Completion for Different Shells
Bash
docs.text:
# Create the completions directory if it doesn't exist
mkdir -p ~/.bash_completion.d

# Generate and save the completion script
recursivist completion bash > ~/.bash_completion.d/recursivist

# Add to .bashrc to load on startup
echo 'source ~/.bash_completion.d/recursivist' >> ~/.bashrc

# Load the completion in the current session
source ~/.bash_completion.d/recursivist

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text:
# Create the completions directory if it doesn't exist
mkdir -p ~/.zsh/completion

# Generate and save the completion script
recursivist completion zsh > ~/.zsh/completion/_recursivist

# Add to .zshrc to load on startup (if not already configured)
echo 'fpath=(~/.zsh/completion $fpath)' >> ~/.zshrc
echo 'autoload -U compinit; compinit' >> ~/.zshrc

# Load the completion in the current session
fpath=(~/.zsh/completion $fpath)
autoload -U compinit; compinit

docs.title: Fish
docs.text:
# Create the completions directory if it doesn't exist
mkdir -p ~/.config/fish/completions

# Generate and save the completion script
recursivist completion fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/recursivist.fish

# Completions will be loaded automatically the next time you start fish
# To load them immediately:
source ~/.config/fish/completions/recursivist.fish

docs.title: PowerShell
docs.text:
# Generate the completion script
recursivist completion powershell > recursivist.ps1

# Create a profile if it doesn't exist (check first)
if (!(Test-Path -Path $PROFILE)) {
    New-Item -ItemType File -Path $PROFILE -Force
}

# Add the completion script to your profile
Add-Content -Path $PROFILE -Value ". $(pwd)\recursivist.ps1"

# Load the completion in the current session
. .\recursivist.ps1

docs.title: Using Shell Completion
docs.text:
Once set up, you can use tab completion with Recursivist commands:

  1. Type a partial command and press Tab to complete it:
recursis[Tab]  # completes to "recursivist"
  1. Type a command and press Tab to see available subcommands:
recursivist [Tab]  # shows visualize, export, compare, etc.
  1. Type a subcommand and press Tab to see available options:
recursivist visualize --[Tab]  # shows --exclude, --depth, etc.
  1. Type a path argument and press Tab to complete the path: 
    recursivist visualize ~/pro[Tab]  # completes to "~/projects/"

docs.title: Completion Features
docs.text:
Recursivist's completion system provides:

  • Command and subcommand completion
  • Option name completion (both long and short forms)
  • Option value completion for some options
  • File and directory path completion
  • Contextual help for available options

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If shell completion isn't working:

  1. Make sure you've sourced the completion script correctly
  2. Verify that your shell's completion system is enabled
  3. Try restarting your shell session
  4. Check for error messages when loading the completion script

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
If you get a "permission denied" error when generating the completion script:

# Make sure you have write permission to the target directory
chmod +w ~/.bash_completion.d

# Or use sudo to generate the script (system-wide)
sudo recursivist completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/recursivist

docs.title: Completion Not Working
docs.text:
If completion doesn't work even after setting up:

# Make sure the script is executable
chmod +x ~/.bash_completion.d/recursivist

# Try sourcing it explicitly
source ~/.bash_completion.d/recursivist

# Check for errors in the script
cat ~/.bash_completion.d/recursivist

docs.title: Zsh Insecure Directories Warning
docs.text:
If you see a warning about insecure directories in Zsh:

# Fix directory permissions
chmod 755 ~/.zsh
chmod 755 ~/.zsh/completion

docs.title: System-Wide Installation
docs.text: For system-wide installation (requires admin privileges):

docs.title: Bash (Ubuntu/Debian)
docs.text: sudo recursivist completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/recursivist

docs.title: Bash (RHEL/CentOS/Fedora)
docs.text: sudo recursivist completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/recursivist

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text: sudo recursivist completion zsh > /usr/local/share/zsh/site-functions/_recursivist

docs.title: Fish
docs.text: sudo recursivist completion fish > /usr/share/fish/vendor_completions.d/recursivist.fish

docs.title: Command Completion Options
docs.text: The tab completion for Recursivist is particularly helpful for:

docs.title: Complex Options
docs.text:
# Tab completion suggests available options
recursivist visualize --sort-by-[Tab]
# Shows: --sort-by-loc --sort-by-size --sort-by-mtime

docs.title: Format Selection
docs.text:
# Tab completion suggests available formats
recursivist export --format [Tab]
# Shows: txt json html md jsx

docs.title: Shell Selection
docs.text:
# Tab completion suggests available shells
recursivist completion [Tab]
# Shows: bash zsh fish powershell

This makes it much easier to use Recursivist's more advanced features without needing to remember all the available options.

docs.title: Visualization
docs.text: The visualize command is the primary way to display directory structures in the terminal with Recursivist. This guide explains how to use it effectively and customize the output.

docs.title: Basic Visualization
docs.text:
To visualize the current directory structure:

recursivist visualize

For a specific directory:

recursivist visualize /path/to/directory

docs.title: Color Coding
docs.text:
By default, Recursivist color-codes files based on their extensions. Each file extension gets a unique color, generated deterministically to ensure consistent visualization:

  • The same extension always gets the same color in all visualizations
  • Colors are generated to be visually distinct between different file types
  • The color scheme provides good contrast for readability

docs.title: File Statistics
docs.text: Recursivist can display and sort by various file statistics:

docs.title: Lines of Code
docs.text:
Calculate and display the number of lines in each file and total lines per directory:

recursivist visualize --sort-by-loc

Output:

📂 my-project (4328 lines)
├── 📁 src (3851 lines)
│   ├── 📄 main.py (245 lines)
│   ├── 📄 utils.py (157 lines)
...

docs.title: File Sizes
docs.text:
Display file sizes with appropriate units (B, KB, MB, GB):

recursivist visualize --sort-by-size

Output:

📂 my-project (1.2 MB)
├── 📁 src (850.5 KB)
│   ├── 📄 main.py (12.4 KB)
│   ├── 📄 utils.py (8.2 KB)
...

docs.title: Modification Times
docs.text:
Show when files were last modified with smart formatting:

recursivist visualize --sort-by-mtime

Output:

📂 my-project (Today 14:30)
├── 📁 src (Today 14:25)
│   ├── 📄 main.py (Today 14:25)
│   ├── 📄 utils.py (Yesterday 18:10)
...

docs.title: Combining Statistics
docs.text:
You can combine multiple statistics in a single view:

recursivist visualize --sort-by-loc --sort-by-size --sort-by-mtime

Output:

📂 my-project (4328 lines, 1.2 MB, Today 14:30)
├── 📁 src (3851 lines, 850.5 KB, Today 14:25)
│   ├── 📄 main.py (245 lines, 12.4 KB, Today 14:25)
...

docs.title: Directory Depth Control
docs.text:
For large projects, it can be helpful to limit the directory depth:

recursivist visualize --depth 2

This will display only the top two levels of the directory structure, with indicators showing where the depth limit was reached:

📂 my-project
├── 📁 src
│   ├── 📄 main.py
│   ├── 📄 utils.py
│   └── 📁 tests
│       ⋯ (max depth reached)
├── 📄 README.md
...

docs.title: Full Path Display
docs.text:
By default, Recursivist shows only filenames. For a view with full paths:

recursivist visualize --full-path

Example:

📂 project
├── 📄 /home/user/project/README.md
├── 📁 src
│   ├── 📄 /home/user/project/src/main.py
│   └── 📄 /home/user/project/src/utils.py

docs.title: Excluding Directories
docs.text:
To exclude specific directories:

recursivist visualize --exclude "node_modules .git"

docs.title: Excluding File Extensions
docs.text:
To exclude files with specific extensions:

recursivist visualize --exclude-ext ".pyc .log"

docs.title: Pattern-Based Filtering
docs.text:
For more precise control, you can use patterns:

# Exclude with glob patterns (default)
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "*.test.js" "*.spec.js"

# Exclude with regex patterns
recursivist visualize --exclude-pattern "^test_.*\.py$" --regex

# Include only specific patterns (overrides exclusions)
recursivist visualize --include-pattern "src/*" "*.md"

See the Pattern Filtering guide for more details.

docs.title: Using Gitignore Files
docs.text:
If you have a .gitignore file, you can use it to filter the directory structure:

recursivist visualize --ignore-file .gitignore

You can also specify a different ignore file:

recursivist visualize --ignore-file .recursivist-ignore

docs.title: Output Example
docs.text:
The visualization output looks like this:

📂 my-project
├── 📁 src
│   ├── 📄 main.py
│   ├── 📄 utils.py
│   └── 📁 tests
│       ├── 📄 test_main.py
│       └── 📄 test_utils.py
├── 📄 README.md
├── 📄 requirements.txt
└── 📄 setup.py

With depth limits, you might see:

📂 my-project
├── 📁 src
│   ├── 📄 main.py
│   ├── 📄 utils.py
│   └── 📁 tests
│       ⋯ (max depth reached)
├── 📄 README.md
├── 📄 requirements.txt
└── 📄 setup.py

With file statistics enabled:

📂 my-project (4328 lines)
├── 📁 src (3851 lines)
│   ├── 📄 main.py (245 lines)
│   ├── 📄 utils.py (157 lines)
│   └── 📁 tests (653 lines)
│       ├── 📄 test_main.py (412 lines)
│       └── 📄 test_utils.py (241 lines)
├── 📄 README.md (124 lines)
├── 📄 requirements.txt (18 lines)
└── 📄 setup.py (65 lines)

docs.title: Verbose Mode
docs.text:
For detailed information about the visualization process:

recursivist visualize --verbose

This is useful for debugging or understanding how patterns are applied.

docs.title: Terminal Compatibility
docs.text:
Recursivist works in most modern terminals with:

  • Unicode support for special characters (📁, 📄, etc.)
  • ANSI color support

If your terminal doesn't support these features, you might see different characters or no colors.

docs.title: Performance Tips
docs.text:
For large directories:

  1. Use the --depth option to limit the directory depth
  2. Exclude large directories you don't need with --exclude
  3. Use pattern matching to focus on specific parts of the directory tree
  4. Avoid using --sort-by-loc for very large repositories as line counting can be time-consuming

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• Export: Save directory structures to various formats
  • Compare: Compare two directory structures side by side

For complete command options, see the CLI Reference.
